div.p:
and friend Simple by your
name,

that calls himself doctor
of physic?

old Windsor way, and every
way

you will also look that
way.

how my heart trobs and
trobs
how full of chollors I am,

I shall be glad if he have
deceived me.

♪ To shallow rivers, to
whose falls

There will we make our
beds of roses,

I have a great
dispositions to cry.
When as I sat in Pabylon--

To shallow rivers, to
whose falls-♪

Yonder he is coming, this
way, Sir Hugh.

♪ To shallow rivers, to
whose falls-♪

from Frogmore, over the
stile, this way.
Pray you, give me my gown;

or else keep it in your
arms.

Keep a gamester from the
dice,

and a good student from
his book,

'Pless you from his mercy
sake, all of you!

What, the sword and the
word!

do you study them both,
master parson?

And youthful still! in
your doublet

and hose this raw
rheumatic day!

There is reasons and
causes for it.

We are come to you to do a
good office,

Yonder is a most reverend
gentleman,

is at most odds with his
own gravity

and patience that ever you
saw.

I have lived fourscore
years and upward;

I never heard a man of his
place,

so wide of his own
respect.

I think you know him;
Master Doctor Caius,

I had as lief you would
tell me

here's the man should
fight with him.

It appears so by his
weapons.

Keep them asunder:
here comes Doctor Caius!

Nay, good master parson,
keep in your weapon.

So do you, good master
doctor.

Disarm them, and let them
question:

let them keep their limbs
whole

I pray you, let-a me speak
a word

Vherefore vill you not
meet-a me?
By gar, you are de coward,
Pray you let us not be

and I will one way or
other

for missing your meetings
and appointments.

have I not stay for him to
kill him?
at de place I did appoint?

As I am a Christians soul
now, look you,

I'll be judgement by mine
host

Peace, I say, Gallia and
Gaul,

Ay, dat is very good;
excellent.

Peace, I say! hear mine
host
Am I politic? am I subtle?

no; he gives me the
potions

Shall I lose my parson, my
priest,

no; he gives me the
proverbs

Give me thy hand,
terrestrial; so.

Give me thy hand,
celestial; so.

Boys of art, I have
deceived you both;

I have directed you to
wrong places:

and let burnt sack be the
issue.

Come, lay their swords to
pawn.

Trust me, a mad host.
Follow, gentlemen, follow.

have you make-a de sot of
us,

he has made us his
vlouting-stog.

I desire you that we may
be friends;

and let us knog our prains
together

to be revenge on this same
scall,
By gar, with all my heart.

where is Anne Page; by
gar,

Well, I will smite his
noddles.

Nay, keep your way, little
gallant;

you were wont to be a
follower,
but now you are a leader.

Whether had you rather
lead mine eyes,
go before you like a man

than follow him like a
dwarf.

O, you are a flattering
boy:

now I see you'll be a
courtier.

Well met, Mistress Page.
Whither go you?

Truly, sir, to see your
wife.
Ay; and as idle as she

may hang together, for
want of company.

I think, if your husbands
were dead,

Be sure of that,--two
other husbands.

Where had you this pretty
weather-cock?

what the dickens his name
is

What do you call your
knight's name, sirrah?

He, he; I can never hit
on's name.

between my good man and
he!

Is your wife at home
indeed?
I am sick till I see her.
he hath no use of them.

He pieces out his wife's
inclination;

he gives her folly motion
and advantage:

and now she's going to my
wife,
A man may hear this shower

pluck the borrowed veil of
modesty

from the so seeming
Mistress Page,

for a secure and wilful
Actaeon;

all my neighbours shall
cry aim.
The clock gives me my cue,

and my assurance bids me
search:

I shall be rather praised
for this than mocked;

that Falstaff is there: I
will go.
I have good cheer at home;

and I pray you all go with
me.

I must excuse myself,
Master Ford.

and I would not break with
her

for more money than I'll
speak of.

We have lingered about a
match

and this day we shall have
our answer.

I hope I have your good
will, father Page.

Ay, be-gar; and de maid is
love-a me:

my nursh-a Quickly tell me
so mush.

What say you to young
Master Fenton?

he will carry't, he will
carry't; '

Not by my consent, I
promise you.

The gentleman is of no
having:

he kept company with the
wild prince

he is of too high a
region;

No, he shall not knit a
knot

with the finger of my
substance:

the wealth I have waits on
my consent,

and my consent goes not
that way.

some of you go home with
me to dinner:
I will show you a monster.

we shall have the freer
wooing

Go home, John Rugby; I
come anon.

I will to my honest knight
Falstaff,

I think I shall drink in
pipe wine first with him;

Have with you to see this
monster.

I warrant. What, Robert, I
say!

as I told you before, John
and Robert,

and when I suddenly call
you,

and without any pause or
staggering

take this basket on your
shoulders:

and carry it among the
whitsters

and there empty it
-- in Datchet-mead --

I ha' told them over and
over;

Be gone, and come when you
are called.

is come in at your
back-door, Mistress Ford,
have you been true to us?

and hath threatened to put
me
if I tell you of it;

for he swears he'll turn
me away.
shall be a tailor to thee

and shall make thee a new
doublet
and hose. I'll go hide me.

Do so. Go tell thy master
I am alone.

Mistress Page, remember
you your cue.

if I do not act it, hiss
me.

we'll teach him to know
turtles from jays.

for I have lived long
enough:

this is the period of my
ambition:

Now shall I sin in my
wish:

I would thy husband were
dead:

I'll speak it before the
best lord;
I would make thee my lady.

alas, I should be a
pitiful lady!

thou hast the right arched
beauty

of the brow that becomes
the ship-tire,

thou art a tyrant to say
so:

thou wouldst make an
absolute courtier;

and the firm fixture of
thy foot

Come, thou canst not
hide it.

Believe me, there is no
such thing in me.

and say thou art this and
that,

like a many of these
lisping hawthorn-buds,

that come like women in
men's apparel,

and smell like Bucklersbury
in simple time;
I cannot: but I love thee;

none but thee; and thou
deservest it.

I fear you love Mistress
Page.

I love to walk by the
Counter-gate,
which is as hateful to me

as the reek of a
lime-kiln.

Well, heaven knows how I
love you;

and you shall one day find
it.

Keep in that mind; I'll
deserve it.

Nay, I must tell you, so
you do;

or else I could not be in
that mind.

here's Mistress Page at
the door,

sweating and blowing and
looking wildly,

and would needs speak with
you presently.

O Mistress Ford, what have
you done?

What's the matter, good
Mistress Page?

having an honest man to
your husband,

to give him such cause of
suspicion!

Out pon you! how am I
mistook in you!

with all the officers in
Windsor,

that he says is here now
in the house

to take an ill advantage
of his absence:
Pray heaven it be not so,

that you have such a man
here!

but 'tis most certain your
husband's coming,

with half Windsor at his
heels,
to search for such a one.
I come before to tell you.
why, I am glad of it;

but if you have a friend
here convey,

call all your senses to
you;

to your good life for
ever.

There is a gentleman my
dear friend;

and I fear not mine own
shame

I had rather than a
thousand pound
he were out of the house.

in the house you cannot
hide him.

O, how have you deceived
me!

if he be of any reasonable
stature,

and throw foul linen upon
him,

as if it were going to
bucking:

--send him by your two men
to Datchet-mead.

He's too big to go in
there. What shall I do?

Let me see't, let me
see't,

Follow your friend's
counsel. I'll in.

Is this your love? Are these
your letters, knight?

I love thee,
none but thee.

Help to cover your master,
boy.

Go take up these clothes
here quickly.

Carry them to the
laundress in Datchet-mead;
why then make sport at me;
then let me be your jest;

How now! whither bear you
this?
Why, what have you to do

You were best meddle with
buck-washing.

Buck! I would I could wash
myself

Ay, buck; I warrant you,
buck;

and of the season too, it
shall appear.

Here, here, here be my
keys:

I'll warrant we'll
unkennel the fox.

Let me stop this way
first.

By gar, 'tis no the
fashion of France;

it is not jealous in
France.

see the issue of his
search.

Is there not a double
excellency in this?

I know not which pleases
me better,

that my husband is
deceived, or Sir John.
What a taking was he in

when your husband asked
who was in the basket!

I warrent he will
have need of washing;

so throwing him into the
water

I would all of the same
strain

for I never saw him so
gross

I will lay a plot to try
that;

and we will yet have more
tricks

Shall we send that foolish
carrion,

and excuse his throwing
into the water;

to betray him to another
punishment?

let him be sent for
to-morrow,

of that he could not
compass.

You use me well, Master
Ford, do you?

Heaven make you better
than your thoughts!

You do yourself mighty
wrong, Master Ford.
Ay, ay; I must bear it.

If there be any body in
the house,

I would not ha' your
distemper

in this kind for the
wealth

You suffer for a bad
conscience:

your wife is as honest a
'omans

as I will desires among
five thousand,

By gar, I see 'tis an
honest woman.

Well, I promised you a
dinner.

I will hereafter make
known to you

but, trust me, we'll mock
him.

I do invite you to-morrow
morning

I have a fine hawk for the
bush.

If there is one, I shall
make two
If dere be one or two,

I pray you now,
remembrance tomorrow

on the lousy knave, mine
host.

to have his gibes and his
mockeries!
by that which we will do

wives may be merry,
and yet honest too!

I see I cannot get thy
father's love;
turn me to him, sweet Nan.
I am too great of birth--,

And that, my state being
gall'd

I seek to heal it only by
his wealth:

other bars he lays before
me,

My riots past, my wild
societies;

And tells me 'tis a thing
impossible

I should love thee but as
a property.
May be he tells you true.

Albeit I will confess thy
father's wealth
I found thee of more value

And 'tis the very riches
of thyself

my kinsman shall speak for
himself.

No, she shall not dismay
me:

would speak a word with
you.

Looks handsome in three
hundred pounds a-year!

And how does good Master
Fenton?
Pray you, a word with you.

O boy, thou hadst a
father!

I had a father, Mistress
Anne;

my uncle can tell you good
jests of him.

how my father stole two
geese
out of a pen, good uncle.

Mistress Anne, my cousin
loves you.

Ay, that I do; as well as
I love

He will maintain you like
a gentlewoman.
Ay, that I will, come cut

under the degree of a
squire.
He will make you a hundred
Marry, I thank you for it;

I thank you for that good
comfort.

She calls you, coz: I'll
leave you.
I ne'er made my will yet,

I am not such a sickly
creature,

I would little or nothing
with you.
if it be my luck, so;

if not, happy man be his
dole!

They can tell you how
things go better than I.

You may ask your father;
here he comes.

thus still to haunt my
house:

Nay, Master Page, be not
impatient.

Good Master Fenton, come
not to my child.
She is no match for you.

for that I love your
daughter

In such a righteous
fashion as I do,

I must advance the colours
of my love

let me have your good
will.

Good mother, do not marry
me to yond fool.

I mean it not; I seek you
a better husband.

Alas, I had rather be set
quick

And bowl'd to death with
turnips!

I will not be your friend
nor enemy:

And as I find her, so am I
affected.

'will you cast away your
child on a fool,

Look on Master Fenton:'
this is my doing.

I thank thee; and I pray
thee,

Give my sweet Nan this
ring:

Now heaven send thee good
fortune!
But yet I would my master

or I would Master Slender
had her;

I would Master Fenton had
her;

I will do what I can for
them all three;

and I'll be as good as my
word;

Well, I must of another
errand

what a beast am I to slack
it!

Go fetch me a quart of
sack;

Have I lived to be carried
in a basket,

like a barrow of butcher's
offal,

and to be thrown in the
Thames?

Well, if I be served such
another trick,

I'll have my brains ta'en
out and buttered,
and give them to a dog

The rogues slighted me
into the river

and you may know by my
size

that I have a kind of
alacrity

if the bottom were as deep
as hell,

but that the shore was
shelvy

and shallow,--a death that
I abhor;

for the water swells a
man;

and what a thing should I
have been

I should have been a
mountain of mummy.
Let me pour in some sack

as if I had swallowed
snowballs

for pills to cool the
kidneys.

By your leave; I cry you
mercy:

Go brew me a pottle of
sack finely.

I'll no pullet-sperm in my
brewage.

I come to your worship
from Mistress Ford.

I have had enough
of ford;

I was thrown into the
ford;

I have my belly full of
ford.

she does so take on with
her men;

to build upon a foolish
woman's promise.

Well, she laments, sir,
for it,

that it would yearn your
heart to see it.

Her husband goes this
morning a-birding;

to come to her between
eight and nine:

I must carry her word
quickly:

she'll make you amends, I
warrant you.

and bid her think what a
man is:

and then judge of my
merit.

Do so. Between nine and
ten, sayest thou?

Well, be gone: I will not
miss her.

I marvel I hear not of
Master Brook;

he sent me word to stay
within:

I like his money well. O,
here he comes.

you come to know what hath
passed

That, indeed, Sir John, is
my business.

Master Brook, I will not
lie to you:

I was at her house the
hour she appointed me.

but the peaking Cornuto
her husband,

comes me in the instant of
our encounter,

spoke the prologue of our
comedy;

and at his heels a rabble
of his companions,
And did he search for you,

As good luck would have
it,

they conveyed me into a
buck-basket.

crammed me in with foul
shirts and smocks,

of villanous smell that
ever offended nostril.

And how long lay you
there?

Nay, you shall hear,
Master Brook,

what I have suffered to
bring this woman

Being thus crammed in the
basket,

were called forth by their
mistress

to carry me in the name of
foul clothes

they took me on their
shoulders;

met the jealous knave
their master

who asked them once or
twice

what they had in their
basket:

he should be a cuckold,
held his hand.

Well: on went he for a
search,

and away went I for foul
clothes.

But mark the sequel,
Master Brook:

in the circumference of a
peck,like a good bilbo,

hilt to point, heel to
head;

and then, to be stopped
in,

it was a miracle to scape
suffocation.

And in the height of this
bath,

when I was more than half
stewed in grease,

to be thrown into the
Thames,

in that surge, like a
horse-shoe;

I am sorry that for my
sake

I will be thrown into
Etna,

as I have been into
Thames,
ere I will leave her thus.

'twixt eight and nine is
the hour,

I will then address me to
my appointment.

Come to me at your
convenient leisure,

and you shall know how I
speed;

You shall have her, Master
Brook;

Master Brook, you shall
cuckold Ford.
Hum! ha! is this a vision?

Master Ford awake! awake,
Master Ford!

in your best coat, Master
Ford.

this 'tis to have linen
and buck-baskets!

I will now take the
lecher;

he cannot creep into a
halfpenny purse,

but, lest the devil that
guides him

Though what I am I cannot
avoid,
yet to be what I would not

if I have horns to make
one mad,

let the proverb go with
me:
